channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Adventure Awaits! Senior Perl roles in Malaysia, Dubai and Malta
item.description: Clever folks know that if you’re lucky, you can earn a living and have an adventure at the same time. Enter our international client: online trading is their game, and they’re looking for Perl people with passion, drive, and an appreciation for new experiences.

item.title: Perl Programmer Opportunity - Join a Prominent Tech Publishing Powerhouse in the Philippines
item.description: Our UK-based client is a global leader in the enterprise technology publishing industry, providing audiences worldwide with stimulating perspectives and unique news on enterprise tech that matters today and tomorrow. They are currently seeking a passionate and exceptional Perl programmer based in the Philippines to join their team.

item.title: Perl and Koha
item.description: August 14-18, 2023, Helsinki, Finland

item.title: TPRC Toronto Part 3 The End Game
item.description: Final day reporting from TPRC 2023.

item.title: TPRC Toronto Part 2
item.description: In the post, get the detailed report of Day 2 @ TPRC 2023.

item.title: Well Back in the Saddle again.
item.description: John sharing his experience of Day 1 @ TPRC 2023 in Toronto.

item.title: The Perl and Raku Conference, Toronto 2023
item.description: Event report by Dave where he shared his experience and recommended talks.

item.title: First report: More than 80% of the crates link to their public VCS
item.description: I have been working on the Rust Digger for more than a month. This is the first repor I created.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: The Perl and Raku Conference 2023 in Toronto
item.description: Please checkout the video of talks presented @ TPRC 2023.

item.title: Moving and Removing
item.description: Perl and Python in action toegether. Enjoy one-liner specially in Python. Well done.

item.title: Shuffling Zeroes
item.description: Interesting dicussion about the various languages feature needed for the task. Highly recommended.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #226
item.description: No operations for Zero Array? Use of List::Util is very handy for the task.

item.title: Gnirsts and nothing left
item.description: Nicely laid out solutions in Perl with detailed analysis. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: Perl one-liner by inhouse guru. Thanks for your contributions.
Array indexes everywhere!
item.description: Like always, we have Raku and PostgreSQL solutions, enough to keep you busy. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 226: Zero Array
item.description: Interesting task analysis for deeper understanding. Thanks for sharing the knowledge with us.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 226: Shuffle String
item.description: Cool comparison of Perl and Raku implementation as always. You really don't want to miss it.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 226
item.description: Z operator of Raku is so handy to get the job done. Cool attempt.

item.title: PWC226 - Zero Array
item.description: Flavio seems to be on mission to get the job done one-liner. Clever coding, well done.

item.title: PWC226 - Shuffle String
item.description: Sweet and short one-liner in Perl and Raku. Great work, keep it up.

item.title: Shuffle Off To Buffalo
item.description: Shuffle or unshuffle? Find out yourself. Great work and thanks for sharing.

item.title: Zero Shuffle
item.description: Array slice in action using Raku. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Shuffled Operations
item.description: Clever use of pack and unpack to get the job done. Thanks for reminder.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 226
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Shuffle String" and "Zero Array" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 227
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks: "Friday 13th" and "Roman Maths". If you are new to the weekly challenge, why not join us and have fun every week? For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: LDAP groups expansion
item.description: Please find working code in Perl to play with LDAP directory.

item.title: Perl v5.36, Debian, and Ubuntu
item.description: Interesting subject being discussed about Perl version in different OS and how to deal with them.

item.title: Modernize Chained Actions in Perl Catalyst MVC
item.description: Latest release of Perl Catalyst is out with enhancements to chained actions.

item.title: "Next Action" - Improving Perl Catalyst Chained Actions
item.description: Perl's Catalyst MVC web framework action chaining is explained in details. Highly recommended.

item.title: Using Postgresql pg_vector for AI: Part 2, Using vectors For Natural Language Processing
item.description: In the blog post you will learn the use of OpenAI to create vector.

item.title: Using Postgresql pg_vector for AI: Part 1, WTF is a Vector Anyway?
item.description: Talk of the town AI is being picked by John in the blog post series. If you are new to generative AI then you should check out it yourself.

item.title: Why we use Perl at our company
item.description: Another success story of use of Perl in a well documented post.

item.title: Perl Catalyst Release 5.90131
item.description: Version 5.90131 of the Perl MVC web development framework Catalyst just hit CPAN.

item.title: #626 - What is Oshun?
item.description:
Hi there,

I am sure you have followed The Perl and Raku Conference 2023 in Toronto whether as attendee or watching the videos. I was fortunate to attend the conference and meet the who's who of Perl Community. The highlight of the conference for me was the keynote, Coming soon ..., presented by Curtis Poe. It was during the keynote, we were introduced to a new project, Oshun. Since the release of Perl v5.38, we have all been introduced to Corinna, a modern OO to the Perl core. Oshun is the next big thing after Corinna. To be honest, it is really cool idea and I can't wait it to be included in the Perl core. I know it is in early stage right now but I am glad it is in safe hand.

I would also like to mention about another talk No one is immune to abuse by Sawyer X. I was lucky enough to be in the audience. In general, we are proud of the friendly and encouraging nature of the Perl community but it is also fact that you do come across few who are not too friendly. I could relate to what was shared in the talk as I have experienced the abuse myself during the early days of [The/Perl] Weekly Challenge. I must confess it took me months to recover from it. Those who are part of the weekly challenge must have noticed it too. I stopped participating in the weekly challenge for sometime and kept myself limited to managing the challenge as opposed to contributing to the weekly challenge in Perl and Raku, writing blog posts and making YouTube videos for the same. I did come back few months later and participated again but it didn't last long.

If you missed the conference this year then you have plenty of time to book your place at The Perl and Raku Conference 2024 which is going to be held in sunny Las Vegas, Nevada.

We also had surprise announcement by Olaf Alders with regard to the Perl Advent Calendar 2023 CFP. I missed the deadline last year and couldn't find a place in the Perl Advent Calendar 2022. I will make sure this time, I submit my proposal well before the deadline. If you have something to share with the rest of the community then I would request you to come forward and submit your proposals.

Last but not the least, the next big event, Perl and Koha Conference 2023 is happening next month. You can find the schedule of the event. I am going to miss the event as it is clashing with my home visit to India. I hope and wish you all have great time.

Thank you Gabod for the space in the editorial of last week newsletter. It means a world to me. Enjoy rest of the newsletter.
item.dc:subject: editorial
